smell_analysis.justification: Every page titled 'Diagram: ...' (pages 1-17) contains visible modeled elements such as use cases, classes/tables, states, or activity nodes; there are no empty diagrams.

The only explicit use case diagram, 'Tubade funktsionaalne allsüsteem' (page 2), shows all named use case ovals (e.g., 'Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Registreeri tuba', 'Unusta tuba') inside the system boundary with association lines connecting them to at least one actor; no use case is clearly left without a linked actor.

On the use case diagram (page 2) each use case name describes a distinct activity such as registering, activating, deactivating, ending, forgetting, or viewing rooms; there are no pairs like 'Add car' vs 'Register car' that describe the same activity while being associated with the same actor.

The package diagram 'Tubade FASiga seotud pädevusalad ja registrid' (page 1) contains uniquely named model elements within its package, such as 'Tubade funktsionaalne allsüsteem', 'Isikute register', 'Klassifikaatorite register', 'Tubade register', 'Töötajate register', and 'Klientide register'; there are no multiple elements with the same primary name in the same package.

In the transformed database diagrams (pages 12-17), repeated values such as an 'isik_id' or various *_kood fields appear only where foreign key relationships are explicitly drawn between tables; there are no clearly redundant copies of the same business data in different tables without foreign key connectors.

Use case names on both the overview text list (page 1) and the use case diagram (page 2) consistently follow a verb-object pattern such as 'Registreeri tuba', 'Aktiveeri tuba', 'Muuda tuba', 'Vaata tubade koondaruannet', and 'Unusta tuba'; there is no mixing of verb-led and noun-led naming styles.

The state diagram 'Toa seisundidiagramm' (page 10) shows transitions from the initial pseudostate into an ordinary state and transitions between all named states ('Ootel', 'Aktiivne', 'Mitteaktiivne', 'Unustatud', 'Lõpetatud'); no state is clearly isolated from the rest of the graph.

In the activity diagram 'Toa lõpetamise tegevusdiagramm' (page 3), each action node such as 'Vaata kõiki tube, mida saab lõpetada', 'Otsi tuba', 'Vali tuba', and 'Lõpeta valitud tuba' lies on a path that starts at 'Algus' and leads towards 'Lõpp'; there is no action node that is unreachable.

All UML-style class diagrams (pages 4-11) show multiplicity indicators such as '1' and '0..*' on associations between classes (e.g., between 'Isik' and 'Isiku roll', between 'Tuba' and its related classifier classes). The transformed database diagrams (pages 12-17) use standard foreign key connectors and crow's-foot-style implied cardinalities, which are exempt by the interpretation rules. There is no clear association line that lacks multiplicities at both ends.

The use case diagram 'Tubade funktsionaalne allsüsteem' (page 2) contains at least 11 central elements in the form of distinct use cases ('Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Registreeri tuba', 'Aktiveeri tuba', 'Muuda tuba', 'Muuda tuba mittaktiivseks', 'Lõpeta tuba', 'Unusta tuba', 'Vaata aktiivseid tube', 'Vaata kõiki tube', 'Vaata kõiki ootel või mitteaktiivseid tube', 'Vaata tubade koondaruannet'), exceeding the threshold of 10 central elements on a single diagram.

In the database diagram 'Tubade register (transformed)' (page 17), the table 'Tuba' has distinct relationship lines to at least six other tables: 'Toa_kategooria_omamine', 'Hoone', 'Toa_seisundi_liik', 'Toa_tyyp', 'Voodi_tyyp', and 'Tootaja' (via keys for registreerija and viimane_muutja). These are drawn as separate foreign key connectors radiating from 'Tuba', giving it 6 or more visible relationships on that diagram and triggering the rule.

Across all diagrams, related elements are laid out at roughly comparable distances; connections such as actors to use cases (page 2), classes in register diagrams (pages 4-11), and tables in transformed diagrams (pages 12-17) do not show any relationship line that is conspicuously more than twice the average element spacing on the same diagram.

All use case names on the use case diagram (page 2) and the activity actions on the activity diagram (page 3) start with active verbs in Estonian such as 'Tuvasta', 'Registreeri', 'Aktiveeri', 'Muuda', 'Lõpeta', 'Unusta', 'Vaata', 'Otsi', and 'Vali'; there are no use cases or actions whose names begin with a non-verb.

Class, table, attribute, and use case names throughout the diagrams (for example 'Isik', 'Kasutajakonto', 'Toa_kategooria', 'Toa_seisundi_liik', 'Tuba', 'Tootaja_rolli_omamine') all have names longer than three characters; no model element is named with 3 or fewer characters like 'id' or 'abc'.

Entity class and table names representing singular domain objects, such as 'Isik', 'Klient', 'Tuba', 'Tootaja', 'Toa_kategooria', 'Voodi_tyyp', 'Toa_seisundi_liik', are capitalized and singular; plural names occur only in register-level containers like 'Isikute register' which are explicitly register tables and are excluded by the interpretation rules.

Attribute and column names in both conceptual and transformed diagrams use lowercase starts (for example 'isikukood', 'e_meil', 'reg_aeg', 'toa_kategooria_kood', 'tootaja_seisundi_liik_kood', 'registreerija_id'); the leading letters of the actual attribute names are lowercase even when prefixed by markers like '*PK' or '*FK', so there is no attribute or column whose name itself starts with an uppercase letter.

Database table names corresponding to singular domain entities, such as 'Isik', 'Klient', 'Tuba', 'Tootaja', 'Riik', 'Hoone', 'Toa_kategooria', 'Toa_tyyp', and 'Voodi_tyyp', are all singular; plural forms occur only in register labels like 'Klassifikaatorite register', which are register tables excluded from this rule.

Class, table, and attribute names do not use type-indicating prefixes like 'tbl_', 'uc_', or 'strName'; instead they use domain-specific names (e.g., 'Isik', 'Kasutajakonto', 'Toa_kategooria', 'tootaja_roll_kood'). The only prefixes present are key-related ones such as PK, FK, pfK, and IXFK on columns or constraints, which are explicitly allowed by the rule.
